"I am for Mr. Roosevelt," said
"Dewey" Penniman, when asked
last week to defend the faith in the
Colonel that is in him, "because he
is not controlled by any party or
trust. Wilson is for the bosses.
Roosevelt stands for the things 1
stand for—regulation of labor and ;
old age'pensions. He can force 1his
' I
bills through Congress with his big
stick. Wilson is too vague; he does •
not state his i)osition on the real ;
issues. Roosevelt has the right
idea about the tariff—to • regulate
the tariff through the Taft Tariff
Commission."
"Why are you.for Wilson," asked
a representative of Tim NEWSLETTF,R of J. Earle Uhler, senior ;
delegate on the Executive Committee of the Wilson Club. "I am for
him," he replied after a moment's
thought, "because his record is more
the record of a statesman and gentleman than of a politician. He is
a good conscientious man of sound
principles. He believes in the :direct election of United States senators, the reduction of the tariff,
and a commission for handling the
trusts."
"Why am I for Taft?" asked G.
V. Rusk, the most outspoken adherent of the President in the
senior class. "I am for him because he has had every trust which
has broken the law of the land
brought before the bar of justice,
whether friendly or hostile to his
administration. The trusts that arc
backing Roosevelt are the trusts
which are being prosecuted by
President Taft. I am for him because he signed the Paine Tariff
fin, which on the whole. provided
lower schedules, and which called
for the establishment of a nonpartisan tariff board. If the Democrats had not nullified that Board
'they would not now 'be able to go
before the country today on the
tariff question. 'I am for Taft because he fought for reciprocity
,which a year ago would have
Drought down the cost of living
without injury to our manufactures.
It is with sorry grace that the
Democrats plead for reduction in
the cost of'living now, when it was
Champ Clark who killed reciprocity.
I am for him because he vetoed
the Democratic tariff bills which
were unfair to thousands of business men and altogether unscientific
in principle; because he has pushed
through the Senate the Workmen's
Compensation Act; because he has

Last Thursday at one. o'clock,
under the auspices of the Hopkins
Arbitration-Literary Society, Miss
Edith Hamilton, president of Bryn
Mawr School, delivered a weighty
speech in favor of woman's suffrage. From start to finish Miss
1..familton held the attention of
every one of the fifty men who
gathered to hear her.
Miss Hamilton began her address by announcing that she had
nothing to say to those men who '
were instinctively interested in new
things; but would address herself
to the conservatives. She pointed
out that as woman's suffrage exists in greater or less degree in
Persia, Siam, Norway, Finland, in
the region of the Caucasus, in Australia, in England, and in six of
our own States, it is no new thing.
If it's good we must help it ; if bad,
fight it. No longer does woman
suffragists believe that the millennium will be ushered in when wornen are given the ballot. Nor- do
they believe that politics will be
greatly purified. But they are striving- for their end because they believe that woman's place is in the
home and that she can competently
fill that place only by exercising the
suffrage. .Today half of the things
which formerly were done in the
home are done outside it: The
baking of bread, the making of
garments, the teaching of children.
Women can supervise these things
only by the exercise of the suffrage,
and only by the exercise of the suffrage can they safeguard the health
and morals of their children.
Next Thursday's meeting of the
Society will be an arbitration meeting-, at which John S. Dickinson,
'13, will read i paper on "How Far
Peace?" There will be other addresses and general discussion.
All students who wish to join the
Society at this time are requested
to be present at this meeting and
hand their names to J. C. Sinclair,
'13. Mr. C. J. Weber, '14, chairman of the Marlmrg Medal Committee, desires all freshmen who
intend to compete for the medal to
hand their names to him within the
next two weeks. This-medal is
offered each year by the Society to
that member of the freshman class
who -submits the best essay On st)me
subject connected with arbitration.
Further information in regard to
the contest may be had from Mr.
Weber.

The Student Council for the year ;
[912-13 met in the Trophy Room '
last Wednesday at five o'clock and
organized. ; John S. Dickinson, '13,
E.
was elected chairman, and
Corner, '14, secretary. The Council consists of F. C. Lee, president
of the Athletic Asociatn;'
J. S.
Dickinson and C. L. Getz, delegates
from the senior class; H. E. Corner
and A. L. Hammond, delegates
from the juniors; C. I. Uhler,
sophomore delegate, and G. D.
Penniman, Jr., freshman delegate.
The Council discussed a tenative
program of measures which it will
recommend in fulfillment of its
duty to adjust relations between
various classes of students at the
University. The two subjects upon
which it was decided to take immediate action were non-fraternity
representation on the Cotillon Board
and the abolition of freshmansophomore football games.
At present the Johns Hopkins
Cotillon Uoard consists of six
members, each one of whom is a
representative of one of the six.fraternities established at the ITniversity. There has been a growing
feeling during the past year or two
that the non-fraternity men, a large
number of whom patronized the
cotillons, should have some representation on the Board. This feeling has at length reached proportions which caused the Council to
think that it should be recognized.
'['lie ideal condition of affairs would
be for the cotillons to be regular
student activities, arranged by a
• board elected by the whole student
body, but it was perceived that the
transition to such a state would not
be effected at once, and it was
therefore decided that ill addition
to the six fraternity men on the
Board there should be four 11011fraternity men, to be elected by the
non-fraternity men of each of the
four classes. F. C. Lee and H. E.
Corner were appointed a committee
to embody this decision in a recommendation and submit it to the Cotillon Board.
The second subject taken up was
the abolition of freshman-sopho• more football games. Because of
the relatively small number of men
upon NVI10111 the classes can draw
for their teams, men feel called
upon to enter these games who
have not had the requisite amount
, of previous training, and who arc
not fit physically Ito play so stiff a
game as football. For this reason

Hopkins put up a beautiful defensive game on Saturday against
Swarthmore at Swarthmore, and
surprised a number of followers
by holding the heavier and more
experienced team to a 40 to 6 score.
Swarthmore outweighed the 'Varsity team twenty pounds to a man,
and taking into consideration the
excellent record the Pennsylvania
team has made this season, many
persons .had expected to see Hopkins overwhelmed by a score much
larger than forty points..
Captain Gillett and Percy Hall
were the particular stars of the losing eleven. Gillett, at fullback,
easily outpunted McKissick, and he
made the two field goals that were
the only points scored by Il'opkins.
Hall .made an excellent record
for himself at right end. He ran
down under a number of punts and
made several. beautiful catches of
Gillett's forward passes.
In the first two quarters Hopkins failed to make a third down.
The team could not push the heavy
opposing line for any great distances. Later, in the third period,
the 'Varsity took a brace and the
team manipulated the ball in better
style. In the last quarter the pigskin was worked downfield three
times within kicking distance of the
goal posts, and two goals from field
were made by Gillett's toe. One
was kicked from the 40 and the
other from the 20 'yard line.
Swarthmore scored a touchdown
a few minutes after the first quarter
began on gains made by two beautiful forward passes, one of which
went for 20 yards.
Three touchdowns were made in
the second period, and then the
Swarthmore coaches beg-an sending
in substitutes. The third quarter
brought another touchdown for the
Garnets, when Clime intercepted
Gillett's pass and ran half the
length of the field to the goal.
:\fter these three periods of scoring by the Garnet eleven, Hopkins
took a brace and became more aggressive. The line held wonderfully well against the heavier opponents and assisted materially in
the two sallies toward the Swarthmore goal posts that gave Gillett
his chances to kick the field goals.
None of the 'Varsity players was
injured in the contest, a fact which
shows that the team was in good
condition.

Israel Abraham Lectures.
Last Tuesday and Wednesday,
Israel Abrahams, reader in Talmudic and Rabbinical literature in
the University of Cambridge, delivered two illustrated lectures in
McCoy Hall, both of which were
comparatively well attended.
The subject of the first lecture
was "Some Ancient Greek Colonies." Professor Abrahams outlined
the early Greek colonization in
Sicily and Italy and along the
shores of the Black Sea. In speaking of the Amazon women warriors, the lecturer remarked that
they would have made capital suffragettes.
The second lecture was on the
subject of "Judas Maccabaeus."
Professor Abrahams traced Greek
history in its relation, to the Jews,
discussing Alexander's conquests,
and his difficulty in using the phalanx in the hills and mountain
gorges of Palestine. The contribt\tions of the Maccabees to Jewish
history and the subsequent developments during the beginning of the
Christian era were discussed. The
lecture closed with an account of
the place of Judas Maccabaeus
among the "nine worthies" of literature.
Both lectures were well illustrated by lantern slides of temples,
trated by lantern slides, adding to
the interest of the discourses.

On Saturday the Hopkins football team will enter on the home
stretch of its schedule by playing
the eleven of Stevens' Institute at
Homewood. In the five remaining
games Hopkins is expected to make
a much better showing than in those
that have been played up to the
present time. The hardest games
are now past, and certainly to have
been defeated by Swarthmore and
Navy was no disgrace.
For the past few years the games
betwen Hopkins and Stevens have
been exceptionally close. Pieper
won the game against Stevens three
years ago by making a touchdown
after a long run. The score was
6 to o. In 1910 Stevens won after
a hard battle by the extremely close
score of 2 to o. Last year Hopkins reversed the preceding year's
score and defeated Stevens 2 to o.
Every indication points to another
very close game on Saturday.
The Western Maryland game the
following Saturday, and the St.
John's game a week later, should
be well worth seeing. St. John's
has a much better record than Hopkins so far, and the interest will
be all the greater on that account.
For several years past it has been
rather a foregone conclusion that
Hopkins would win, and the attendance has not been as large as it
would have been had the teams
seemed more evenly matched. It
is to be hoped that the number of
persons at the game this year will
exceed even the record-breaking
number of 7,000 which attended
the game in 1909.
As an extra attraction on Saturday, the annual class-rush between
the sophomores and freshmen will
be held between the halves of the
Stevens football game. President
Branham of the sophomore class
will select twenty men to represent
the class of 1915, and President
Primrose will do likewise in the
freshman class. The twenty contestants on each side will have to
be examined and passed upon by
Dr. Abercrombie before they will
be allowed to compete. The rush
will be refereed by President C. L.
Getz of the senior class and ten
judges.

I

By taking up the cotillon situation the Student Council shows that
it does not intend to shirk the duties for which it was called into
being. Those duties at bottom
all amount to one thing--the adjustment of relations between opposing classes of interests in the
University. The Council has already moderated between class-officers .and class-members by undertaking .to fix the dates of class elections ; and between freshman and
sophomores by supervising the
freshman election. But these undertakings were relatively unimportant ; in taking .up the cotillon question the council approaches for the
first time a matter of prime importance.
This is not the place to go into
the merits of the question. How
the Council has dealt with the
situation, and what were its reasons
for coming to the conclusion that
it did are matters of interest and
significance, but after all of less
interest and significance than the
bare fact that a duly elected representative body of students took
up the question at all. In this fact
is to be read the beginning- of a new
era at Hopkins ; an era in which
old customs will no longer be followed among the students merely
because they are customs, but \yin
be subjected by a student committee to a rigid scrutiny to see whether
they are just, beneficial. and necessary, or merely unjust and dangerous. The Student Council has taken
a step further in this direction by
recommending the abolition of the
freshman-sophomore football game.
This game has long been a feature
of every season. There are many
who will be sorry to see it go, but
experience seems to have shown
conclusively that it is one of the

The scrub football team played
its first game at Tome on Saturday,
and was beaten by a score of 32
to O. The game was closer than
the score would indicate, for the
scrubs held well until the latter
part of the third period, when there
was a general demoralization in the
Hopkins ranks which resulted in
Tome's scoring four touchdowns in,
a little over ten minutes.
By consistent gains through the
line, Captain Weems of Tome carried the ball over the opal line soon
'' but this was
after the game started,
the only time the Hopkins goal was
in 'danger till the end of the third
quarter. It was impossible for the
light scrub backs to gain through
their opponents' line, and,few first
downs were made.
For Tome, Weems was everywhere, and far outclassed any other
man on the team. Nelson played
well at tackle for the scrubs, and
Wells and Baker starred at the
ends. The tackling of this pair was
the feature of the game from a
Hopkins point of view.

Lecturer From

Spain.

Last Monday the University was
visited by an ex-president of the
University, of Oviedo, Rafel
camiro. Senor Alcamiro is one of
the two directors general of prima6t education of Spain,: and is
not famous in his native land only,
but is one of the foremost historians in the world today.
While here, Senor Alcamiro delivered in French, a most interesting lecture to the departments of
History and of Romance on "Tolerance and Intolerance in Spain."
The lecture, which dealt chiefly
with the history of early' Spain, covered not merely tolerance in political and religious matters, but in all
other fields as well. The lecturer
dwelt in detail upon the tolerance
towards the Jews, which people he
declared, until 1200, when they
were expelled, enjoyed all religious
and political freedom consistent
with the .? age. Senor Alcamiro
vent on to contradict the general
impression that wars between the
Arabs and Spaniards were religious
struggles.
The lecture was well attended by
the public as well as by students.
The Spanish minister to Washington was among those present.

Last Thursday at one. o'clock,
under the auspices of the Hopkins
Arbitration-Literary Society, Miss
Edith Hamilton, president of Bryn
Mawr School, delivered a weighty
speech in favor of woman's suffrage. From start to finish Miss
1..familton held the attention of
every one of the fifty men who
gathered to hear her.
Miss Hamilton began her address by announcing that she had
nothing to say to those men who '
were instinctively interested in new
things; but would address herself
to the conservatives. She pointed
out that as woman's suffrage exists in greater or less degree in
Persia, Siam, Norway, Finland, in
the region of the Caucasus, in Australia, in England, and in six of
our own States, it is no new thing.
If it's good we must help it ; if bad,
fight it. No longer does woman
suffragists believe that the millennium will be ushered in when wornen are given the ballot. Nor- do
they believe that politics will be
greatly purified. But they are striving- for their end because they believe that woman's place is in the
home and that she can competently
fill that place only by exercising the
suffrage. .Today half of the things
which formerly were done in the
home are done outside it: The
baking of bread, the making of
garments, the teaching of children.
Women can supervise these things
only by the exercise of the suffrage,
and only by the exercise of the suffrage can they safeguard the health
and morals of their children.
Next Thursday's meeting of the
Society will be an arbitration meeting-, at which John S. Dickinson,
'13, will read i paper on "How Far
Peace?" There will be other addresses and general discussion.
All students who wish to join the
Society at this time are requested
to be present at this meeting and
hand their names to J. C. Sinclair,
'13. Mr. C. J. Weber, '14, chairman of the Marlmrg Medal Committee, desires all freshmen who
intend to compete for the medal to
hand their names to him within the
next two weeks. This-medal is
offered each year by the Society to
that member of the freshman class
who -submits the best essay On st)me
subject connected with arbitration.
Further information in regard to
the contest may be had from Mr.
Weber.

The Council discussed a tenative

recommend in fulfillment of its
duty to adjust relations between
various classes of students at the
University. The two subjects upon
which it was decided to take immediate action were non-fraternity
representation on the Cotillon Board
and the abolition of freshmansophomore football games.
At present the Johns Hopkins
Cotillon Uoard consists of six
members, each one of whom is a
representative of one of the six.fraternities established at the ITniversity. There has been a growing
feeling during the past year or two
that the non-fraternity men, a large
number of whom patronized the
cotillons, should have some representation on the Board. This feeling has at length reached proportions which caused the Council to
think that it should be recognized.
'['lie ideal condition of affairs would
be for the cotillons to be regular
student activities, arranged by a
• board elected by the whole student
body, but it was perceived that the
transition to such a state would not
be effected at once, and it was
therefore decided that ill addition
to the six fraternity men on the
Board there should be four 11011fraternity men, to be elected by the
non-fraternity men of each of the
four classes. F. C. Lee and H. E.
Corner were appointed a committee
to embody this decision in a recommendation and submit it to the Cotillon Board.
The second subject taken up was
the abolition of freshman-sopho• more football games. Because of
the relatively small number of men
upon NVI10111 the classes can draw
for their teams, men feel called
upon to enter these games who
have not had the requisite amount
, of previous training, and who arc
not fit physically Ito play so stiff a
game as football. For this reason

Hopkins put up a beautiful defensive game on Saturday against
Swarthmore at Swarthmore, and
surprised a number of followers
by holding the heavier and more
experienced team to a 40 to 6 score.
Swarthmore outweighed the 'Varsity team twenty pounds to a man,
and taking into consideration the
excellent record the Pennsylvania
team has made this season, many
persons .had expected to see Hopkins overwhelmed by a score much
larger than forty points..
Captain Gillett and Percy Hall
were the particular stars of the losing eleven. Gillett, at fullback,
easily outpunted McKissick, and he
made the two field goals that were
the only points scored by Il'opkins.
Hall .made an excellent record
for himself at right end. He ran
down under a number of punts and
made several. beautiful catches of
Gillett's forward passes.
In the first two quarters Hopkins failed to make a third down.
The team could not push the heavy
opposing line for any great distances. Later, in the third period,
the 'Varsity took a brace and the
team manipulated the ball in better
style. In the last quarter the pigskin was worked downfield three
times within kicking distance of the
goal posts, and two goals from field
were made by Gillett's toe. One
was kicked from the 40 and the
other from the 20 'yard line.
Swarthmore scored a touchdown
a few minutes after the first quarter
began on gains made by two beautiful forward passes, one of which
went for 20 yards.
Three touchdowns were made in
the second period, and then the
Swarthmore coaches beg-an sending
in substitutes. The third quarter
brought another touchdown for the
Garnets, when Clime intercepted
Gillett's pass and ran half the

Israel Abraham Lectures.
Last Tuesday and Wednesday,
Israel Abrahams, reader in Talmudic and Rabbinical literature in
the University of Cambridge, delivered two illustrated lectures in
McCoy Hall, both of which were
comparatively well attended.
The subject of the first lecture
was "Some Ancient Greek Colonies." Professor Abrahams outlined
the early Greek colonization in
Sicily and Italy and along the
shores of the Black Sea. In speaking of the Amazon women warriors, the lecturer remarked that
they would have made capital suffragettes.
The second lecture was on the
subject of "Judas Maccabaeus."
Professor Abrahams traced Greek
history in its relation, to the Jews,
discussing Alexander's conquests,
and his difficulty in using the phalanx in the hills and mountain
gorges of Palestine. The contribt\tions of the Maccabees to Jewish
history and the subsequent developments during the beginning of the
Christian era were discussed. The
lecture closed with an account of
the place of Judas Maccabaeus
among the "nine worthies" of literature.
Both lectures were well illustrated by lantern slides of temples,
trated by lantern slides, adding to
the interest of the discourses.

On Saturday the Hopkins football team will enter on the home
stretch of its schedule by playing
the eleven of Stevens' Institute at
Homewood. In the five remaining
games Hopkins is expected to make
a much better showing than in those
that have been played up to the
present time. The hardest games
are now past, and certainly to have
been defeated by Swarthmore and
Navy was no disgrace.
For the past few years the games
betwen Hopkins and Stevens have
been exceptionally close. Pieper
won the game against Stevens three
years ago by making a touchdown
after a long run. The score was
6 to o. In 1910 Stevens won after
a hard battle by the extremely close
score of 2 to o. Last year Hopkins reversed the preceding year's
score and defeated Stevens 2 to o.
Every indication points to another
very close game on Saturday.
The Western Maryland game the
following Saturday, and the St.
John's game a week later, should
be well worth seeing. St. John's
has a much better record than Hopkins so far, and the interest will
be all the greater on that account.
For several years past it has been
rather a foregone conclusion that
Hopkins would win, and the attendance has not been as large as it
would have been had the teams
seemed more evenly matched. It
is to be hoped that the number of
persons at the game this year will
exceed even the record-breaking
number of 7,000 which attended
the game in 1909.
As an extra attraction on Saturday, the annual class-rush between
the sophomores and freshmen will
be held between the halves of the
Stevens football game. President
Branham of the sophomore class
will select twenty men to represent
the class of 1915, and President
Primrose will do likewise in the
freshman class. The twenty contestants on each side will have to
be examined and passed upon by
Dr. Abercrombie before they will
be allowed to compete. The rush
will be refereed by President C. L.
Getz of the senior class and ten
judges.

By taking up the cotillon situation the Student Council shows that
it does not intend to shirk the duties for which it was called into
being. Those duties at bottom
all amount to one thing--the adjustment of relations between opposing classes of interests in the
University. The Council has already moderated between class-officers .and class-members by undertaking .to fix the dates of class elections ; and between freshman and
sophomores by supervising the
freshman election. But these undertakings were relatively unimportant ; in taking .up the cotillon question the council approaches for the
first time a matter of prime importance.
This is not the place to go into
the merits of the question. How
the Council has dealt with the
situation, and what were its reasons
for coming to the conclusion that
it did are matters of interest and
significance, but after all of less
interest and significance than the
bare fact that a duly elected representative body of students took
up the question at all. In this fact
is to be read the beginning- of a new
era at Hopkins ; an era in which
old customs will no longer be followed among the students merely
because they are customs, but \yin
be subjected by a student committee to a rigid scrutiny to see whether
they are just, beneficial. and necessary, or merely unjust and dangerous. The Student Council has taken
a step further in this direction by
recommending the abolition of the
freshman-sophomore football game.
This game has long been a feature
of every season. There are many
who will be sorry to see it go, but
experience seems to have shown
conclusively that it is one of the
ustoms which are unnecessary and
dangerous. Its abolition will cause
a gap in the events of the year, but

each side tries to convince the other

can be excused if they vote for
their party or their prejudices ; but

his opinion, if due cause is found,

Scrubs Lose to Tome.

The Cleaner with a Hopkins Education
419 N. Charles
229 N. Howard
216 W.Fayette

The scrub football team played
its first game at Tome on Saturday,
and was beaten by a score of 32
to O. The game was closer than
the score would indicate, for the
scrubs held well until the latter
part of the third period, when there
was a general demoralization in the
Hopkins ranks which resulted in
Tome's scoring four touchdowns in,
a little over ten minutes.
By consistent gains through the
line, Captain Weems of Tome carried the ball over the opal line soon
'' but this was
after the game started,
the only time the Hopkins goal was
in 'danger till the end of the third
quarter. It was impossible for the
light scrub backs to gain through
their opponents' line, and,few first
downs were made.
For Tome, Weems was everywhere, and far outclassed any other
man on the team. Nelson played
well at tackle for the scrubs, and
Wells and Baker starred at the
ends. The tackling of this pair was
the feature of the game from a
Hopkins point of view.

Lecturer From

Spain.

Last Monday the University was
visited by an ex-president of the
University, of Oviedo, Rafel
camiro. Senor Alcamiro is one of
the two directors general of prima6t education of Spain,: and is
not famous in his native land only,
but is one of the foremost historians in the world today.
While here, Senor Alcamiro delivered in French, a most interesting lecture to the departments of
History and of Romance on "Tolerance and Intolerance in Spain."
The lecture, which dealt chiefly
with the history of early' Spain, covered not merely tolerance in political and religious matters, but in all
other fields as well. The lecturer
dwelt in detail upon the tolerance
towards the Jews, which people he
declared, until 1200, when they
were expelled, enjoyed all religious
and political freedom consistent
with the .? age. Senor Alcamiro
vent on to contradict the general
impression that wars between the
Arabs and Spaniards were religious
struggles.
The lecture was well attended by
the public as well as by students.
The Spanish minister to Washington was among those present.
